hazards.name: Tornado Warning
hazards.summary: A dangerous rotating column of air that can cause severe damage in minutes.
hazards.before: Know your safe room (basement, interior room on lowest floor), and keep helmets, sturdy shoes, and a whistle ready.
hazards.during: Go to your safe place immediately away from windows. Cover your head and neck with your arms, a mattress, or heavy blankets.
hazards.after: Watch for broken glass, gas leaks, and downed power lines. Check on neighbors and listen for official updates before traveling.
hazards.alt: NWS tornado warning map with a red polygon over part of a county.

hazards.name: Tornado Watch
hazards.summary: Conditions are favorable for tornadoes to form in the watch area.
hazards.before: Review your safety plan, charge phones and power banks, and identify nearby sturdy shelters.
hazards.during: Stay weather-aware, keep local radar or alerts open, and be ready to move quickly if a warning is issued.
hazards.after: Continue monitoring the weather. Watches may be upgraded to warnings or allowed to expire.
hazards.alt: NWS tornado watch graphic with counties shaded yellow.

hazards.name: Severe Thunderstorm Warning
hazards.summary: Storm with damaging winds, large hail, and intense lightning is occurring or imminent.
hazards.before: Secure outdoor items, move vehicles under cover if it is safe, and close windows and doors.
hazards.during: Stay indoors and away from windows. Avoid using corded electronics and plumbing during intense lightning.
hazards.after: Check for damage such as downed limbs or hail dents. Report hazards like downed lines to authorities.
hazards.alt: NWS severe thunderstorm warning map with a red polygon highlighting the affected area.

hazards.name: Severe Thunderstorm Watch
hazards.summary: Conditions are favorable for storms that could become severe.
hazards.before: Bring loose items indoors and review your shelter options before storms develop.
hazards.during: Monitor radar and warnings. Be ready to move to an interior room if a warning is issued.
hazards.after: Keep monitoring until the watch expires, as storms can form late in the watch period.
hazards.alt: NWS severe thunderstorm watch map with counties shaded yellow.

hazards.name: Flash Flood Warning
hazards.summary: Rapid, life-threatening flooding is occurring or will occur soon.
hazards.before: Know if you live in a flood-prone area. Plan alternate routes that avoid low water crossings.
hazards.during: Never drive through flooded roads. Turn around, donâ€™t drown. Move to higher ground immediately.
hazards.after: Avoid walking or driving through standing water. It may hide washed-out roadways or debris.
hazards.alt: NWS flash flood warning graphic highlighting a red polygon over a region.

hazards.name: River Flooding
hazards.summary: Rivers and streams rise above their banks over hours or days.
hazards.before: Move valuables and important documents above expected flood levels. Consider sandbags if directed.
hazards.during: Follow evacuation instructions. Do not go around barricades or enter closed areas.
hazards.after: Return home only when authorities say it is safe. Wear boots and gloves when cleaning up.
hazards.alt: Brown, fast-moving floodwater rushing through a wooded area.

hazards.name: Winter Storm Warning
hazards.summary: Heavy snow, ice, or a combination that can severely disrupt travel and power.
hazards.before: Stock up on food, water, and medications. Charge devices and gather blankets, flashlights, and batteries.
hazards.during: Stay off the roads if possible. Dress in layers and avoid overexertion while shoveling.
hazards.after: Watch for slick spots and falling ice. Check on neighbors, especially those who are older or live alone.
hazards.alt: NWS winter storm warning graphic with a large region shaded pink.

hazards.name: Dangerous Wind Chill
hazards.summary: Cold air and wind combine to remove heat quickly from exposed skin.
hazards.before: Plan shorter time outdoors and prepare proper outerwear including hats, gloves, and face protection.
hazards.during: Limit exposed skin and stay dry. Watch for early signs of frostbite or hypothermia.
hazards.after: Warm up gradually indoors and avoid very hot water on numb skin.
hazards.alt: NWS dangerous cold graphic showing wind chill values well below zero.

hazards.name: Blowing Snow & Whiteout
hazards.summary: Strong winds reduce visibility, making travel extremely dangerous.
hazards.before: Delay travel if possible. Share your route and expected arrival time with someone you trust.
hazards.during: If you must drive, go slowly with headlights on. If stranded, stay with your vehicle.
hazards.after: Clear snow from exhaust pipes before running the engine. Watch for snowdrifts on roads.
hazards.alt: Vehicles driving in near-whiteout conditions on a snowy road.

hazards.name: High Wind Warning
hazards.summary: Winds strong enough to knock down limbs, power lines, and unsecured objects.
hazards.before: Secure trash cans, patio furniture, and loose items. Park vehicles away from large trees.
hazards.during: Stay indoors and away from windows. Avoid parking or standing under trees and power lines.
hazards.after: Be alert for fallen branches, debris, and downed lines. Assume downed lines are live and keep back.
hazards.alt: NWS high wind warning map with a large region shaded orange.

hazards.name: Wind Advisory
hazards.summary: Winds can make driving difficult and blow around unsecured objects.
hazards.before: Secure light outdoor items and use extra caution if driving high-profile vehicles.
hazards.during: Keep both hands on the wheel while driving and watch for sudden gusts on bridges and open areas.
hazards.after: Check for minor damage like fence issues or small branches on roofs and yards.
hazards.alt: NWS wind advisory graphic with a map and text describing wind speeds.

hazards.name: Excessive Heat Warning
hazards.summary: Dangerous heat and humidity can cause heat illness quickly.
hazards.before: Plan outdoor activities for early morning or evening. Identify cool places to go if you lose AC.
hazards.during: Drink plenty of water, take breaks in the shade, and never leave people or pets in parked cars.
hazards.after: Continue hydrating and check on vulnerable friends or neighbors who may have been affected.
hazards.alt: NWS graphic explaining extreme heat watch versus warning.

hazards.name: Heat Advisory
hazards.summary: Hot conditions where prolonged exposure may cause heat stress.
hazards.before: Adjust outdoor plans and wear light, loose clothing.
hazards.during: Take frequent breaks, use sunscreen, and watch for signs of heat exhaustion.
hazards.after: Cool down indoors and rehydrate. Seek medical care if symptoms of heat illness persist.
hazards.alt: NWS slide describing excessive heat impacts and heat headlines over several days.

hazards.name: Frequent Lightning
hazards.summary: Repeated cloud-to-ground lightning strikes near your location.
hazards.before: Know the saying: When thunder roars, go indoors.
hazards.during: Move inside a substantial building or hard-topped vehicle. Avoid corded phones, plumbing, and metal surfaces.
hazards.after: Wait at least 30 minutes after the last rumble of thunder before resuming outdoor activities.
hazards.alt: Nighttime thunderstorm with multiple lightning bolts branching across the sky.

hazards.name: Large Hail
hazards.summary: Ice stones falling from storms that can damage vehicles, roofs, and windows.
hazards.before: Move vehicles into a garage or under cover if time allows. Stay tuned to warnings.
hazards.during: Stay away from windows and skylights. Protect yourself from glass if hail becomes very large.
hazards.after: Carefully inspect roofs, vehicles, and windows for damage and leaks.
hazards.alt: Very large hailstone being measured with a tape measure.
